>>27911755
That's great bro, I'm from Montreal so it's a similar landscape. Here is my advice in no particular order:

- tostart you need a car, a vacuum cleaner (even a shopvac will do initially, you don't need to get fancy), a variety of mops, a shitload of microfibre cloths, some squeegees ans glass cleaning detergent, some general detergent (you can get them in bulk at specialty stores, or just at Home Depot or th equivalent.
Liability insurance (should cost you about $600-700 for a 1-2 mil policy).
Company registration.
You can try to rawdog it without the latter 2, but clients ask if you have insurance about half the time.

-A logo for company documents like estimates, and business cards.

-A pair of balls for cold calling.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27912287
Meant for

>>27911942

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27911942

Next, you look up Google maps and plan your routes. You will be walking around, in person, knocking on doors and introducing your company and inspecting businesses for your estimates.
Protip: bugman software firms are some of the easiest clients to land, they like to cluster together in repurposed old industrial buildings like factories and power stations. A small office is 2 or 3 hours weekly or biweekly, you do the math. The benefit here is the convenience of several jobs being in the same large building. You find these places by looking for "software" and then checking the streetview to see if it's a massive building. Advertise heavily wherever you see these places clustered.
Also look for: non-chain gyms of various kinds, commercial kitchens, dental and other medical offices, small-scale and artisanal manufacturing, bike shops etc.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27911942

You walk into each place, find the owner/boss, and say "hi, my company does commercial cleaning for offices/kitchens/warehouses like this one, how are you guys doing in terms of ckeaning?"

You will get some rejections, others will say that maybe one day, others yet will say incredibly encouraging things like "we just got rod of th old crew, they were missing scheduled cleanings" or "yeah, we need someone".
If it's a maybe or a yes, say you make them a cost estimate if they's like, and ask if what they have in mind is weekly, or biweekly.
As they show you around the place, TAKE NOTES about features such as rugs, sealed floors, desks etc. Because you will include some of those features in your proposal to them later on.
When you're done, say you'll have a price estimate for them shortly, exhange business cards, Boomer handshake or whatever, and leave. Make sure you have notes on the place, or you will forget.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27911942

Once you have prospects, it's time to make proposals for them.
Estimate $35 an hour. A 2-room office is about 1.5-2 hours. Larger is more, you'll learn over time and if you drastically underestimate then clients will understand you're new and won't be offended if you tactfully ask them to renegotiate later on. In fact, everyone will treat you like gold if you don't miss sessions and don't drop the quality of your work over time. Mainly they love the regularity with which "the place cleans itself".

On the proposal inckude an intro saying it's a cost estimate for [frequency] cleaning of [company] location.
Include a bullet point list of what this will entail (glass surfaces, sweeping, mopping, garbage, dusting etc). Customize this list by mentioning the features you jotted down during your tour.

Next day, you take these proposals and bring it to them IN PERSON.
I know it seems awkward and cumbersome, but doing this makes you and your stupid proposal stick in their memory because they've now seen you twice. Drop of off, say "my pleasure, let me know if any questions", and go cancassing for some more new prospects.

Pretty soon, you will have calls and emails asking to schedule cleanings. Once they contact you agree to sign a standard service contract (find a template online,) come over, meet them, get the keys, and you're now in business.

I found per hour more useful because of places with lots of desks, or kitchens with many involved little steps for example.
Really estimating becomes almost automatic very quickly. It's not a major issue and like I said, you can correct your mistakes later on.
For yourself, you begin to see at a glance how many hours of work a place will be. For the client, you can present it in terms of square meters if you want to make a more professional impression.

Another thing: these contracts can be SOLD to other cleaning companies. The going rate is 5 months' fees for them to take it over from you. One guy I knew made his living basically finding clients and selling them almost immediately to other cleaners.
And another: if the company eventually becomes a GOING CONCERN then it might profide he funding for your next move in life. Look up how much such companies sell for in your area to gain an idea.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27904399
You being an empath isn't the issue here, you can understand the pain of others without feeling like shit about it. Heck, there are dark empaths - people who are deeply in tune with emotions of others but revel in the pain they cause.

The issue at hand is that you get easily emotional when witnessing the pain of others. The advice I'd give is fairly similar to those who get emotional of witnessing their own failures - Understand that pain is a natural part of life, but most of the time it's only a big deal if you make it so. Becoming frustrated with or wallowing in pain will damage you way more than the pain itself. Missing a shot in a football game? Unfortunate but not unbearable. It doesn't damage or scar you physically, you can still play in the future and hit other shots, it doesn't ruin any valuable relationships... it's hardly anything tragic.

Learn to separate tragedy from pain. Pain isn't evil. Through it we learn that putting our hand on a stove is a very bad thing. Through failures and mistakes we learn.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>27910920
I want practical advice from people who have been through something similar to this

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: The same skills you use for success with fitness apply to other things in life. You need to manage your time, address weaknesses, do something hard consistently, and understand the reward comes far later than the action. The skill set to succeed is already there and you have demonstrated it. From here you need to set goals with clearly defined end points, like finishing all your reports this week by Wednesday so you can start new projects, or flossing every morning for the whole month. The trick to meeting these goals is to visualize the end result that you want more than the mindless scrolling or distraction you do in the meantime. When you can make the connection that your actions for now impact the result of your progress to these goals (assuming you want them enough), you will automatically use your already developed skills to get there.

Well...
> mom/sister/cat in old home dream
This is your mind's idea of home. You mentioned that you deeply miss your cat, but your mom and sister being present likely means you're on good terms with them too. Regardless of how you feel about them, this is an expression of nostalgia and the warmth of your family you felt when you were younger and in your old home
> shotgun dream
Guns symbolize masculine energy. Not sure how you feel about holding and shooting a shotgun, but I can infer that you felt a little powerful in your dream. When you said "it's just a dream", you became lucid and started vividly experiencing everything. Lucid dreams tend to fizzle out after you become aware; you wondering if it wasn't a dream was likely your brain realizing that you were lucid while still trying to take in the vivid experience.

>>27911067
>What do? Are the meds really that important?
Hey OP, mentally ill anon here who is recently on the mend for once in life. I’ll keep it simple:

No, they aren’t important. They simply numb your emotions and slow your racing thoughts so you can weather some harsh environments emotionally. That’s all. Think of dentistry—they inject your gums with a numbing agent so you can withstand teeth getting pulled. SSRI meds are precisely the same but for the mind.

They will not cure your depression. They will not fix your life. They will not mend a broken heart and they won’t correct a damaged soul. That will take more than meds. But the good news is, it’s a simple thing. Talking.

You can talk your way out of depression if you align your speech with your heart and speak the absolute truth about your pain. From the pain of childhood all the way until today. That is unironically the ‘cure’. Understanding how you became like this, and then forgiving yourself. In other words, fully processing your pain.

SSRIs can get in the way of this. You will need your misery to process it. If it’s numbed you won’t make long-term healing. However IF you are in a rotten circumstance (dysfunctional family, abusive relationship, harsh living environment) the meds are useful as an ‘armor’ to keep you going until you are out of the shitty situation.

Once that’s achieved, you come off of them and begin the work of healing yourself by exploring your pain and talking to others about it with full heart and vulnerability.

posts.com: How do you get discipline when you're undisciplined?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Friends and family can be really helpful in this situation. Don't be afraid to ask for help with accountability.

Here's what I do: I plan two things for myself: one thing that will be my reward if I get something done, and one thing that I will get no matter what. Then, I tell a friend/family member that I really need to get x done before I can get my reward, can you help me stay accountable? That could be them checking up on you, you sending a photo of progress, etc. If you get it done, yay! if you don't, don't worry: you still have that second thing that you're gonna get no matter what. That way you don't feel like you're punishing yourself. Self punishment is the key to losing motivation. Good luck OP <3

Couple of things.

One. You ever notice how discipline of one’s self is absolutely out of the modern zeitgeist? Literally it is the thing globo homo wants the least for its slaves.

Now, having discipline is a life long and wholistic practice. Again, anathema from what modern globo homo wants for you.

Start with goals. Day goals, week goals, year goals, life goals.

Set up a routine.
Use alarms to remind you. Use the mental picture of achievement of goals to keep you honest.

Also remember that a tired, poorly fed, or intoxicated mind has a much much much harder time being disciplined. So give yourself 8 hours of good rest. Eat at consistent times and have enough nutrition.

Lastly, discipline is a muscle. So exercise is slowly and work into bigger reps.

You are totally correct that no one wants to hear about your problems, for the most part. There are many, many exceptions, but most people don't care. Very, very few will actually like hearing about your issues, but they are the sort of caring and sensitive people who probably already liked you.
You can, in theory, talk to girls about your problems but you should default to stoicism. The exceptions are so few that you will never be able to actually vent to her. For instance, issues from the distant past are okay while more contemporaneous ones are usually not. Remember that you are supposed to be her rock and guide. There is a huge difference between letting someone know how you are feeling in a mature and healthy way vs shitting all over the place like a moody teenager, or worse - depending upon your girl for emotional support.
You just sound like a boring person, to be honest. Hating stuff isn't a personality trait. It's fun and can be cool to bond over, but you can't talk about it all the time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Ah, another classic case where the most likely solution to this is to start trying some new things. The more unique experiences you have to talk about, the less you have to rely on talking about your past and your issues. And it could be anything! Read a new book, go to a zoo, eat 50 pieces of gum, it could be literally anything.

Also, it may help if you train yourself to speak more positively about things. It can be easy to focus on what sucks. Challenge yourself by finding gratitude in the little things. "Damn, I had to spend an hour in traffic today... but it gave me lots of time to listen to this new album!" "Ugh, stepped in dog shit. Well now I have an excuse to buy new shoes!" Really push yourself to find gratitude. Good luck OP.

>How to stop talking about my problems
Don’t. Please do NOT buy into the bullshit that modern society passively believes; negativity, disagreeableness, and ‘bad’ emotions are fucking IMPORTANT.

It’s what makes us all human. The human being ought to have access to—and experience—the entire spectrum of emotion. Positive AND negative and everything in between! We should (and are healthy for) oscillating between the two polarities multiple times in a day. Hell it’s also normal to have a mix of emotions from both sides of the emotional spectrum, positive & negative at the same time.

It is also vital to fucking process and externalise these emotions, ESPECIALLY the negative ones. That means speaking them in a healthy way, as often as we feel it necessary. Because if you don’t? You internalise it all. You eventually identify with them. You become depressed, anxious or mentally imbalanced.
And if you keep suppressing and holding in negativity (which is FIFTY FUCKING PERCENT 50% of the felt human experience) like this then you stand to become neurotic as fuck.

Anyone who tells you anything contrary to what I have told you is either a fucking liar, or an overly-agreeable neurotic mess.

>>27911896
Nobody but super nerds care about philosophy. It’s interesting, I love studying it and it has actively made my life better… but it’s also meta-commentary on life rather than being life, so people respond to people who quote philosophers the same as people who quote the Bible.

Most neurotypical people live in the moment. They live off their experiences and the people around them, enjoying social interaction for its own sake and taking life at face value. They value the EFFECTS of a well-studied inner life, in that it imbues you with wisdom, confidence and resilience, but the process of taking life apart, creating a model for how best to live and examining your own worldview are painful, dreary and often tedious work.

Besides which, being attracted to someone is more than just about fulfilling a list of requirements that correlate with romantic success. Above all you have to have chemistry and this exists in the fuzzy realm of emotion, completely divorced from cold logic.

You’re (probably) on the spectrum, so you rely on cold logic to get through life. Cold logic isn’t enough to succeed at human relationships and can actively alienate people, but you’re too lazy to do the work of developing your emotional intelligence and too arrogant to admit that you even have a problem.

This rejection should be a lesson for you. Learn it, or it’ll keep happening.

Good luck to you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27911980
You know what? I’ll break down what you did wrong:

1) You cannot simply try to impress someone and have them be attracted to you because of it. It’s tempting to try, but it never works. Be impressive, by all means, but this is an enhancer rather than the root of attraction.

2) You asked her out without a hint that she even likes you. People communicate attraction in non-verbal ways and by flirting. If you’re unable to read the tea leaves or are getting no signal, you have no business asking someone out. Learn to tell the difference between common courtesy, friendliness and attraction.

3) You put her on the spot by asking her out in front of her friend. Given that she wasn’t attracted to you in the first place, her choices were to publicly reject you or say yes to avoid making a scene. You played yourself here.

4) Your best bet now is to play it cool. Don’t avoid her, or be cold. Treat her as she’s asked to be treated. If it comes up, play it off like it’s no big deal “Gee, I misread THAT situation haha. My bad. Thought I saw something that wasn’t there. Hope I didn’t make things too awkward. Oh well. I’ll see you around.”. It’ll be awkward for the first little bit, but it’ll be forgotten by the group soon enough. Don’t ever ask her out again though. Not ever. Anything you can salvage reputationally from this situation will be destroyed if you reveal yourself to be a simp holding a candle for a girl who rejected him.

>>27906395
In Protestantism a conservative (hates trannies) church is pretty much going to accept the literal interpretation of Genesis pretty much every time. I think the degenerates in the mainline Protestant branches scared the rest of them into thinking that accepting leeway there is a path to modernism. The exception to this is probably the Anglican groups which tend to be far more lenient in their confessions and therefore you are more likely to find a priest/pastor there who agrees with you. Conservative Anglican churches exist you just need to look around, in the states we have the ACNA as well as like a million little splinter groups, idk about Canada. But also most evangelical denominations (Baptist, Charismatic, Non-denom, etc) do not have any kind of overarching hierarchical structure in their churches and they are usually self-governed. In these cases you could very well find a conservative church that also accepts a nonliteral interpretation of Genesis, but it might difficult.

The stance on creation is pretty unimportant in the grand scheme of things in your Christian life. Finding a church that agrees with you on every single little doctrinal issue, especially if you've really thought through this stuff, is extremely rare. Focus on finding a church close to you that you can agree with on the big picture shit. For example my theology is in line with Lutheranism pretty broadly, but the LCMS in the states prefers the literal interpretation of Genesis. I literally just choose not to care, it's not like that will be a requirement for you to believe as a lay person in any reasonable church.
Do this: >>27907609

Rome and the East are options, but I think they have more problems and caveats that you need to tackle before jumping ship. Please seriously consider the theological, historical, and philosophical ramifications of those traditions if you wish to go that route. It isn't as simple as the larping shitposters on this board would have you believe.

I saw a pigeon from my window view, huddled in it's own adipose, in the sunlit straw in my garden. Normally I watch blackbirds and they are really anxious. But the pigeon just sat there, eyes blinking as if it were about to drift off. Concernless.
The next day a pigeon was dead in my driveway.
I help people, but it does nothing. Zero sum acceptance on their behalf. I thought I could try emulating Christ, offering my existence to others - turns out it depends on the magnanimity of your own soul in their eyes... I am already dust. I am *merely* obliged the way that a stone with googly eyes stuck on might be by a ditzy empath. I am anthropized only because I look human, but people know. Just a few words out of my mouth, or a few seconds of watching the way my eyes (fail to) read them, and they know that I was made with only a single foot in this world. Not even a dud, but a kind of simulacrum of a person. They turn their brains off when they talk to me to keep themselves sane. Exposure to my true self, which is my mere self, my lame and dull self, would be enough to turn them into shadows. They use the weight of time on my rung - that which takes me so long to do normal things - that prevents me from experiencing intimate connection. I don't ask, I don't plead. I just fall further and further away from comprehension. I feel like I have temporal dementia. I am losing sense of everything while feeling like it all makes sense. posts.sub: Giving Feedback to Emotionally Sensitive Person
posts.com:
Tips on giving feedback/advice to someone very emotionally sensitive?

I, 26M, have a friend 23M, that i moved in with a couple of years ago. The gist of it is that this guy's got a lot of problems- Aspergers, ADHD, bi-polar meds. When we first moved in he told me to let him know when he's making certain mistakes because he has aspergers and doesn't always know, but every time anyone ever says anything negative or constructive towards him, or gives advice or really anything, sometimes it wont even be directed at him and he'll take it super personally, shut down, get insecure etc.

Once we moved in, he latched onto me and my friends really quickly and it's felt suffocating at times. For more context, we were both students in a student home and I barely knew him, only knew that I would sometimes run into him in the kitchen, liked video games and seemed cool. So when we both disliked our landlord being a dick and doing dumb things we found a new house together. It was only then that we really became friends and I learned just how many problems this guy has. It's gotten to a point where my friends and I are really not in the mood to play games with him sometimes, and other times we just let him go on his weird righteous rants, tangents etc instead of telling him to be quiet or give him advice on something cause it's easier to just endure his stuff instead of telling him to cool it down then having him get all depressed on us.

It's very tiresome, he's always unconsciously looking for validation from us, tilting in video games, and it's just hard. In the past I had to have a serious conversation to him and now he doesn't yell at my friends in video games anymore, but it was still a hard convo to have and he's still pretty high-maintenance and difficult to be around. I think about how I've done similar things in an old group I was exiled from but I genuinely am not sure how I would have talked to that version of myself either.

posts.name: A girl that will break the rules
posts.com:
There is no advice except now you know what it's like to have an abusive friend that doesn't actually want to get better. They want to blame you for all their problems and then they wonder why they are alone.
They cannot stand conflict involving their mannerisms. When they said they want you to criticise them and make them understand, it was a lie.

Basically, you have to stop being such a fucking asshole all the time. Don't worry; I'll elaborate more. Your family history is sad, but not surprising. It definitely fits a profile. I would know; I'm one of them.
So you need to learn to stop pigeonholing people (yourself included) by their interests, learn to find common ground, and learn to read the room to figure out when people don't want to hear your shit. If you want a family of your own, this is the MINIMUM.

Video games are a huge part of my life. I grew up as a shut-in in a hometown my family moved to, away from their family. I had no family support, even when my dad got cancer -- my community around me decided to just crack cancer jokes, even just days after the funeral.

I played games as an escapism. Online multiplayer. The people on there are still friends a decade later. Some I've had lunch with IRL. One helped me move across the country and I have a solid career because of him.

But in that time, I always felt it was the lack of anime/games that kept me from liking the average normie IRL. To me, the idea of something like Twitch.tv was this amazing pretense. A whole website dedicated to people showing off games they like too and communicating with them? Surely no such thing would flourish -- there aren't enough people.
But we have it today. And when you look at it, even with people in the same realm of interests -- it's all scantily clad porn and shit tier memes and takes.

As I grew older, I realized it wasn't the interests that helped me make connections to people and that I only hated people who liked sports because they're normies -- I just fucking hate the average person.

It’s totally normal to not have the same interests as other people. Part of learning to get along with people and have fun with them is to simply recognize that you aren’t interested in what they’re currently talking about, but that you can still listen to them so that they feel appreciated and cared about. Then they will probably do the same thing for you whenever you talk about what they aren’t interested in. Once you build that trust, you can explore things you both like and more easily have a pleasant/fun relaxed time together. You don’t even need to have ANY similar interests, honestly. You just need to be comfy with eachother and be able to communicate without feeling tense. If you can do that, you can be friends with anyone you want.

Just develop a passing interest in some normie things so that you have more to talk about, Anon. Remember always that while it’s good to have standards, you are also doing other people and yourself a disservice by judging everyone else in advance and shutting yourself off to those relationships. We are social creatures, after all, and talking to normies occasionally doesn’t mean you have to become one.

Consider involving yourself in a few borderline hobbies. Guns, cars and history are common ones that both autists and normies share. You can also build a friendship pretty easily by humoring someone and allowing them to teach you some of the surface level stuff surrounding their hobby. People don’t get to feel useful very often outside of work and it makes them feel good to share things they know with someone new. You can learn a new hobby and make friends at the same time.

>>27909239
I'm a nurse, my wife is a 3rd year medical resident. I can't say what you should do, but once you decide don't be a bitch. You need to fully commit. If you start right now, it will probably be 2 years to get all of your pre-med classes out of the way to be able to apply to med school. You should apply to some MD schools but apply to DO schools as well (look it up of you don't know what a DO is). DO schools are easier to get accepted. If you're really hard up, look into carribean schools, although doing clinical rotations with them sounds like a nightmare. Once you graduate you have to do a residency to actually learn how to be a doctor. I think there is a specialty with a 2 year residency (can't think of what it is rn), family medicine has a 3 year residency, internal medicine is usually 4 years, surgery is 5 years, and neurosurgery will take you 7 years. Theres a bunch of other residencies out there, look them up. While you're a resident you'll be making about $60k/year. You'll be working 80+ hours a week. Once you finish residency you can practice as a "real" doctor or you can do a fellowship in a subspecialty if you want more training in a specific area. You will still be in several hundred thousand dollars of debt by now, but you can have most of it forgiven if you're willing to work somewhere rural/a shithole. Basically you're looking at ten years minimum to start practicing. If you like people, I'd say look into family or internal medicine. Since you're on 4chan I'm going to assume you're a misanthrope so you should do something with more procedures like surgery, cardiology, gastroenterology, or urology. If you really hate people you can do radiology or pathology; you'll have very little interaction with patients.

Some alternatives could be CRNA, CAA or PA. They are well paid, but not as much as an MD/DO. School is much shorter, but path to CRNA is pretty long since it requires nursing school plus 5 years nursing experience. And NPs are gay.

Consider the following:
1. Most things that are typically masculine can be applied to you even as a woman, you can be as masculine, tomboyish, butch or what have you as you like without involving hormones and destructive surgery.
2. Those that can't, can't be achieved through medical procedures either.
Testosterone won't make you as strong as a man and transitioning won't make anyone see you any differently.
Those that would accept a hypothetical transition would also accept you if you wanted to be a woman that behaves in a typically masculine way, those that go "durr you're a girl why are you X Y Z" wouldn't change their mind even if you did transition.

The discussion about gender reassignment feels like an absolute regression to me, we went from your sex dictating your preferences and behavior to "boys can like pink and girls can play with firetrucks" to your preferences and behavior dictating your sex.
I really think there's no reason you can't be the person you want to be without going through destructive procedures.
A transition can only approximate masculine features like hair or some ridiculous simulacra of a penis (and it's never going to be an actual penis, just like you can't graft some liver tissues together to form a kidney), and those will never be "close enough" that it would satiate your dysphoria.
Everything else can be achieved without going through processes like that.

There's nothing wrong with preferring guys as company and not fitting the stereotypical idea of a woman, you're not a mistake, you're an individual.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27905345
Meditation/yoga unironically helps. Or prayer/calisthenics if you need trad style. Basically find a habit/exercise that focuses your mind with your body. Yoga and mindful meditation work for me and millions of suburbanites and city heathens far from nature and gods. Pick up hiking and breathing exercises for all I care.

Also other suggestions like reading help. Drawing helps me. Truth is its all a way of getting meandering imagination to work at something. Even if the something is pointless its at least pointlessly involved with something physically outside the mind. This challenges the mind more than your own daydreaming. Wears it out. Doesnt mean its a cure all.

Think of the imaginative daydream part of your mind as a young labrador dog in a small apartment. Fucker wants to do shit. But the owner is in a restrictive neighborhood and dog has to keep good and quiet. Weirdly the dog has an anxious habit of pacing often, endlessly bored and wasting the owners rest time making small whines for attention. But the simple fix isnt just walk the dog but exercise it. Get the lab running and introducing it to new smells new dog butts new plants and run it more. Wear the dog out and the dog wont have as much energy to restlessly pace the small apartment.

So figure out how to wear your brain out. Cant draw and too lazy to learn? Write a journal. Write a historical fiction novel with no goal of publishing them put it on ao3 one day. Read weird books over watching weird shows because reading at least requires your imagination to do some lifting.

>>27906563
Yeah I have had this problem since I was young. Wasted my teens and 20s doing this. Trust me the cure is doing stuff.

Nowadays I let myself daydream cause at least its distracts me from overthinking real world bullshit out of my control. I guess thats all daydreaming ever is but at least I am now conscious of it enough to control it.

The doing creative stuff or reading and mental stimulating hobbies (example tabletop games might be something you get into that leads to friends at least) help to let out the restless imagination. But the more mental meditative habits build your ability to redirect from restless daydreaming to more restful creative hobbies so do try both. Also exercise and lifting. Lifting helped me in that it gave me guilt free time to daydream but it also distracted me from daydreaming as I got more focused on why the fuck isnt my form right? If you can daydream well enough while doing some exercise thats a great way to get it out too. Biking and hiking are my favorite ways. Swimming in the summer is great to do.

Sometimes you cant force stop the daydreaming but you can force yourself to do some menial exercise or do the dishes while daydreaming. Makes the tasks easier. Almost makes them fun and makes you less guilty about time wasted daydreaming.

Dont waste too much daydreaming time inert is all.

Just relating my personal experience, going from being fit in high school and college to an office job where my weight doubled in a very short period of time, due to a combination of factors ranging from bad eating habits to stress and anxiety, and probably underlying mental health issues. I missed out on about 7 years of my life before getting it under control, and it's sad because being fat is no fun.

My method was, joined a gym two blocks from work. Ate a big plate of my favorite food for lunch (Lebanese = chicken, rice, potatoes, salad. hot garlic sauce, yum). After work went to the gym, got on the elliptical that had a built-in-TV and put on Stargate SG1 and Stargate Atlantis that ran back to back and distracted my mind while pushing my body to the limit. Yes, sometimes it felt like I was going to die. Either skipped dinner or had leftovers from lunch. But 6 months later I was fit again.

Sounds like her life needs a *drastic* change, does she want to lose weight or not?

Me and my husband married when we were 18 and 20 respectively. Marriage didn't change the dynamic of our relationship, or take our youth away. Things only got better since marrying a year ago. We still do stupid young adult/teenage shit and feel more committed and devoted to each other. Now we ARE stuck together and now we don't have to worry about breaking up over random shit, or cheating on each other. Marriage makes you want to work on problems together no matter what.

As a young wife my responsibilities haven't changed since getting married. I still do my husband's laundry, I still meet up with my friends, I still go to college. My mom and dad still treat me like their youngest daughter.

As for moving in together, I learned a lot from my husband and he has learned a lot from me. We have grown up together, and I think that has been one of the most beautiful things we have gotten out of our marriage.

I am not telling you to get married, but I am telling you that marriage doesn't really change the living dynamic with the other person. Take her in and live together. She needs to understand that she slowly needs to start growing up, but that she's always got you around. Treat moving in together as a joint task, where you both have to work as a team to make things easier for yourself. You can't just let her do nothing until you feel like she is grown up. She won't be able to grow up without contributing to the household in any way.

TLDR: marriage doesnt change shit + discuss with her living arrangements. see what she would be comfortable doing and where she feels like her limits would be at

posts.name: Anonymous

>>27909645
Any of those things can cause trauma, it’s only controversial because the word can imply so much beyond the mental state. Having trauma doesn’t always mean that you went through something horrible that should never happen to anyone. The reverse is also true: a horrible or morally reprehensible event doesn’t always cause trauma. Trauma just means that you in particular are stuck on that moment or time in a pathological way. It just means you have something you need to work on, maybe with help from others. But it doesn’t mean anyone in particular should be blamed for what happened to you or that anyone has to feel sorry for you.

I used to do this a lot, reddit and twitter were my go-to.
Eventually, reddit got more and more censor heavy. I'd get banned from subs and not bother to make a new account. So I stopped reading comment threads on things I knew I would argue with. /r/politics is just... a disaster. for example. Occasionally i would type up a comment and then just not post it because, it really doesn't matter whatever this persons response will be, and I can avoid myself a stupid headache.

Now, if I see a redditor saying something really questionable, I just look at their account and see where they post and how frequently. Most people are genuinely normal, with a variety of interests, just a different opinion. Some people spend a lot of time in certain flavors of crazy. Many people just have way too much time, so they spend it by arguing on reddit. They aren't serious and you are not going to win or change their mind.

Engaging with comments can be a healthy and intellectually stimulating experience in moderation, so I understand the appeal, but if you must, choose your battles carefully. But my advice for stopping is to stay away, and if you must, look with passing interest. Remember, all of this is excessively fleeting and 99% of it is valueless.

Meanwhile, on twitter, I got banned there too. Although my "death threat" (using navy seals copypasta) ban was a misunderstanding, the only regret I have from it is that it pushed me to 4chan. On twitter, I'd argue, and looking at the things i was posting before my ban, I was more toxic and heated than I should ever be. It draws you in. Now and then, ill look at random tweets and look around, and often time, someone is posting something astoundingly stupid that needs calling out, but its not worth it. posts.sub: Why am I so bad at taking social criticism?
posts.com:
I'm a former aspie (severely autistic in high school) who's mostly managed to turn things around. I'm now in my early 20's and relatively socially well-adjusted. One of the biggest things I still struggle with however is taking social critique; when someone tells me after the fact 'hey, that joke was kind of hurtful' I find myself dwelling on it for hours after and completely shut down. My sense of self-worth takes a hit. While I'm completely fine taking professional criticism, when it's personal I find myself doubting everything from start to finish, from 'what did I say' to 'are these people REALLY my friends?' even when I'm aware it's an utterly benign thing and they're quite justified putting me in my place.

What's triggering this intense social reaction? Searching for it got me nowhere except the most broad advice possible relating to taking criticism. How can I stop taking this so incredibly personally?
